issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares numberOfTutors as an int, but the solution implementation declares the field as short and uses a short parameter for the constructor and setter. This creates a type/signature mismatch: students reading the UML (or tests expecting int) will expect an int attribute and int constructor/setter parameters, but the solution uses short. This difference can confuse students about the intended type and may cause compatibility problems with tests or expected signatures (passing an int to a parameter typed short requires narrowing and can fail to compile in some usages).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of numberOfTutors consistent with the problem UML and other attributes: change the field, constructor parameter and setter parameter to int (i.e., private int numberOfTutors; public Lecture(..., int numberOfTutors) { ... } and public void setNumberOfTutors(int numberOfTutors) { ... }). This preserves the intended design and avoids signature/type mismatches students or tests may expect.
